AI_QUALITY_FAILURES.reasoning: ATLAS/AI prematurely concluded the behavior was “normal” (no traffic in the selected window) despite the customer repeatedly stating there was traffic and the issue started after a firmware upgrade. This downplayed a real product/service malfunction later supported by engineering-style analysis (roll-up chain issue) and logs (buffer overflow). The AI responses were long, generic, and asserted “no evidence of malfunction” without actually validating traffic existence via device health/rollup checks.
evidence: [2025-11-04T18:27:14+00:00] ATLAS: “The ‘Data not available for selected period’ message occurs when no traffic has been recorded… This is a normal behavior… It does not indicate a malfunction…”
[2025-11-09T07:32:38+00:00] ATLAS: “This behavior is in line with normal Exinda operation; there is no evidence of a firmware or reporting engine malfunction.”
[2025-11-07T06:29:38+00:00] Customer: “there was traffic over the link on the mentioned period, but it was not present on exinda subnet report.”
[2025-11-14T08:54:07+00:00] Human (Rishi): “problem is almost certainly in the data-roll-up chain (datad / monitor / statisticsd) rather than capture.”
[2025-11-27T09:50:56+00:00] Human (Syed): “collectord process is failing… buffer overflow… prevents data from being aggregated for the 'Last 24 Hours' reports.”

AI_WALL_LOOPING.reasoning: Customer was repeatedly met with AI-authored explanations that the blank graphs were due to ‘no traffic’ and asked to keep verifying parameters, while the customer kept insisting traffic existed and requesting a call. The AI repeated the same conclusion across multiple public updates (11/04 and 11/09) without moving to deeper troubleshooting (logs/services) until much later, contributing to a loop-like experience.
evidence: [2025-11-04T18:27:14+00:00] ATLAS concludes issue is normal ‘when no traffic has been recorded’
[2025-11-09T07:32:38+00:00] ATLAS repeats: “message… appears only when no traffic is recorded… no evidence of… malfunction.”
[2025-11-14T08:32:06+00:00] Customer: “can you schedule a call because from last 1 month we are only sharing data for verification.”

IGNORING_CONTEXT.reasoning: Support/AI did not incorporate key customer-provided context: (1) issue began after firmware upgrade, (2) affects all subnets, (3) customer asserted traffic existed during the windows that showed blank ‘Last 24 Hours’. AI continued to attribute it to ‘no traffic.’ Later, after the customer attached diagnostics/PDF, support again questioned whether files were uploaded, prompting the customer to complain about repeated requests.

[2025-11-19T04:20:37+00:00] Customer: “can you tell us that how many times you need same data. Have you checked previous update on this ticket provides by us?”
[2025-11-20T15:48:22+00:00] Support: “Did you previously upload these, as I do not see them attached to this ticket?” (customer perceives repeated request / not reviewing prior updates)

RESPONSE_DELAYS.reasoning: There were severe response gaps (weeks) with multiple customer follow-ups asking for updates and escalation details. The ticket shows long periods of inactivity before any substantive support action occurred.

PREMATURE_CLOSURE.reasoning: The transcript does not show the case being closed; the customer is still actively requesting a call, escalation contacts, and a troubleshooting plan after receiving corrective steps.

P1_SEV1_MISHANDLING.reasoning: Customer escalated with severity tagged as “data_loss” and repeatedly stated business-impacting urgency (no reports after upgrade, all subnets, 1+ month delay). Handling remained slow, with weeks of silence and generic explanations rather than rapid escalation/engagement. Customer also requested escalation matrix/contact details and did not receive them in the provided timeline.
